1.6.How does Trading Work
When trading, the user profit if the market price moves in the same direction as the user’s speculation; however, if it takes the opposite
direction, the user incur a loss. It’s important to note that trading is inherently risky and could lose more than expected if don’t take the
appropriate risk management steps. Trading happens between two parties and often involves a dealer network. No central, physical
location only a virtual network of participants. Timings 24/7. Contracts are Customized. Counterparty risk, assets can be more volatile,
and can be traded on leverage, which means there’s a risk of losing more than the deposit

https://avishkanirmitha.github.io/karbon-doc/ 3/33
Introduction
1.1.Purpose
This platform facilitates effortless trading by allowing users to establish personalized settings, thereby enabling trades to be executed
automatically and requiring minimal human intervention. This platform could potentially assist in closing trades automatically when they
reach a profitable point. This streamlined approach ensures a user-friendly experience that stands out from traditional trading platforms
1.2.What is Trading
Trading is the buying and selling of financial instruments in order to make a profit. These instruments range from a variety of assets
assigned a financial value that can go up or down. Trading involves vigorous participation in the financial markets compared to
investing, which works on a buy-and-hold strategy. The success of trading is dependent on the ability of a trader to be profitable over a
period of time.
A trader is a person who gets involved in buying and selling a financial asset in any financial market. He or she can buy or sell either for
himself/herself or on behalf of another individual or institution. The main difference between an investor and a trader is the duration for
which he or she holds on to the asset.
A trader is a person who engages in the short-term purchasing and selling of equity either for an institution or for themselves.
1.3.What is a Candlestick
A candle stick is a type of price chart used in technical analysis that displays the high, low, open, and closing prices of a security for a
specific period.
wherein each candlestick details a single day’s trading. It has three essential features:
The body, which represents the open-to-close range
The wick, or shadow, that indicates the intra-day high and low
Max No Of Trades(Long and Short)
Long 
Maximum number of open long trades means, the user is not allowed to open the long trades more than the selected number. If
the user tries to open more trades “Karbon blocked this trade due to a maximum number of running long trades” message will be
displayed
Shor t 
Maximum number of open short trades means, the user is not allowed to open the short trades more than the selected number. If
the user tries to open more trades “Karbon blocked this trade due to a maximum number of running short trades” message will be
displayed
Leverage
Leverage is the ability to control a large position with a small amount of capital. It is a double-edged sword that can magnify both gains
and losses. The leverage is the amount of money that a trader is willing to risk on a trade. It is important to set the leverage to a level
that is comfortable for the trader and that will not cause financial hardship if the trade is lost.
Leverage types

In this take action, users can define a profit or loss percentage and position size that need to close. If the trade PnL% hits that given
value, the action will trigger immediately.
Responsive image

Change leverage is a feature that allows users to change the leverage of the trade. If the trade PnL% hits that given value, the action will
trigger immediately.
Ex: In this stage, the trade will change the leverage to isolated 10x at negative 50% PnL.
Change Leverage Type
Change leverage type is a feature that allows users to change the leverage type of the trade. If the trade PnL% hits that given value, the
action will trigger immediately.

trade is $5, with 20x leverage, the total position size is equal to 100%, and with the current market price, you can buy 0.001 BTC for $100.
In bybit, the minimum close/open quantity in BTC is 0.001 BTC (tick size). that minimum close/open quantity is different for every pair. In
this configuration, the stage is set as 50% close, which is equal to 0.0005 BTC. In this scenario, bybit rounded the value to 0.001 because

The body, which represents the open-to-close range
The wick, or shadow, that indicates the intra-day high and low
pattern indicators that are available on the platform. Essentially, the strategy differs from the CandlePatternsMultiple strategy only by
calculated indicator count and by the way the list of indicators gets compiled.
This real body represents the price range between the open and close of that day's trading. When the real body is filled in or black (also
red), it means the close was lower than the open. If the real body is white (or green), the close was higher than the open.
1.4.What is a Candle Indicator
This indicator paints each candle green, red, or blue depending on whether the buy/sell pressure for that candle is bullish, bearish, or
neutral.
1.5.How to Use Indicator
When the directional movement index indicator shows more buying pressure than selling pressure, the candle will appear lime green.
This indicates bullish buying pressure. When the directional movement index indicator shows more selling pressure than buying
pressure, the candle will appear red. This indicates bearish selling pressure. When the directional movement index indicator shows the
same amount of buy and sell pressure, the candle will appear blue. This indicates neutral buy/sell pressure. 8 Use the color changes to
see if there is more buying or selling to pinpoint reversals and understand current market buying. Wait to enter or exit positions until the
candles turn the opposite color.

Repurchase
Repurchase is a feature that allows users to repurchase the trade. If the trade PnL% hits that given value, the action will trigger
immediately.
Ex: In this stage, the trade will repurchase 50% of the opened trade at negative 50% PnL.
Reset after Swing
In Karbon platform We can use 2 deferent methods in hedge mode.
Reset after Swing
In this mode, users can create a hedge trade that will be reset its stages after hit opposite side 1st stage For a example : if trade is
at P4 stage and going down to hit N.1. after hit N.1 positive stages reset and it became P.entry stage. If negative stage is
repurchase, that quantity will be dropped with small profit at latest entry price. For that It create TP order in Bybit
No reset after Swing
In this mode, users can create a hedge trade that will not be reset its stages after hit opposite side 1st stage For a example : if
trade is at P4 stage and going down to hit N.1. after hit N.1 positive stage remains P.4 stage.

response.answer: According to the provided context, trading is the buying and selling of financial instruments in order to make a profit. It involves the participation in the financial markets, unlike investing which is a buy-and-hold strategy. The success of trading is dependent on the ability of a trader to be profitable over a period of time.
response.context:
Introduction
1.1.Purpose
This platform facilitates effortless trading by allowing users to establish personalized settings, thereby enabling trades to be executed
automatically and requiring minimal human intervention. This platform could potentially assist in closing trades automatically when they
reach a profitable point. This streamlined approach ensures a user-friendly experience that stands out from traditional trading platforms
1.2.What is Trading
Trading is the buying and selling of financial instruments in order to make a profit. These instruments range from a variety of assets
assigned a financial value that can go up or down. Trading involves vigorous participation in the financial markets compared to
investing, which works on a buy-and-hold strategy. The success of trading is dependent on the ability of a trader to be profitable over a
period of time.
A trader is a person who gets involved in buying and selling a financial asset in any financial market. He or she can buy or sell either for
himself/herself or on behalf of another individual or institution. The main difference between an investor and a trader is the duration for
which he or she holds on to the asset.
A trader is a person who engages in the short-term purchasing and selling of equity either for an institution or for themselves.
1.3.What is a Candlestick
A candle stick is a type of price chart used in technical analysis that displays the high, low, open, and closing prices of a security for a
specific period.
wherein each candlestick details a single day’s trading. It has three essential features:
The body, which represents the open-to-close range
The wick, or shadow, that indicates the intra-day high and low
1.6.How does Trading Work
When trading, the user profit if the market price moves in the same direction as the user’s speculation; however, if it takes the opposite
direction, the user incur a loss. It’s important to note that trading is inherently risky and could lose more than expected if don’t take the
appropriate risk management steps. Trading happens between two parties and often involves a dealer network. No central, physical
location only a virtual network of participants. Timings 24/7. Contracts are Customized. Counterparty risk, assets can be more volatile,
and can be traded on leverage, which means there’s a risk of losing more than the deposit

Reset after Swing
In Karbon platform We can use 2 deferent methods in hedge mode.
Reset after Swing
In this mode, users can create a hedge trade that will be reset its stages after hit opposite side 1st stage For a example : if trade is
at P4 stage and going down to hit N.1. after hit N.1 positive stages reset and it became P.entry stage. If negative stage is
repurchase, that quantity will be dropped with small profit at latest entry price. For that It create TP order in Bybit
No reset after Swing
In this mode, users can create a hedge trade that will not be reset its stages after hit opposite side 1st stage For a example : if
trade is at P4 stage and going down to hit N.1. after hit N.1 positive stage remains P.4 stage.

data.message: What is the way to register online?

response.answer:
To register online, you can sign up by email or phone number. This is applicable for both Bitget and Bybit accounts. 

1. Sign up by email: You need to provide your email and password, and then verify your account by entering a verification code sent to your email.
2. Sign up by phone number: You need to provide your phone number and password, and then verify your account by entering a verification code sent to your phone number.

data.message: What are the user types in fintech applications?

response.answer:
The user types in Karbon, as described in the provided document, are:

1. Default User: A default user is created after the signing-up process.
2. Admin User: Responsible for implementing and maintaining security services, such as adding users, building profiles, or managing general site administration.

This platform facilitates effortless trading by allowing users to establish personalized settings, thereby enabling trades to be executed

1.2.What is Trading
Trading is the buying and selling of financial instruments in order to make a profit. These instruments range from a variety of assets
assigned a financial value that can go up or down. Trading involves vigorous participation in the financial markets compared to
investing, which works on a buy-and-hold strategy. The success of trading is dependent on the ability of a trader to be profitable over a
period of time.
A trader is a person who gets involved in buying and selling a financial asset in any financial market. He or she can buy or sell either for
himself/herself or on behalf of another individual or institution. The main difference between an investor and a trader is the duration for
which he or she holds on to the asset.
A trader is a person who engages in the short-term purchasing and selling of equity either for an institution or for themselves.

data.message: What are the operational steps of trading?

response.answer:
Based on the provided context, the operational steps of trading can be broken down into the following stages:

1. **Setting up Trade Size**: The user sets the trade size, which is the amount of money they are willing to risk on a trade.
2. **Executing the Trade**: The user initiates the trade, and the platform executes it based on the user's settings and market conditions.
3. **Monitoring the Trade**: The user monitors the trade's progress, watching for any changes in the market that may impact the trade's outcome.
4. **Closing the Trade**: The user can close the trade when they reach their desired profit or loss threshold, or when the trade hits a predetermined stage (e.g., P4 stage).
5. **Reset after Swing**: In hedge mode, the trade can be reset after hitting an opposite side's first stage, allowing the user to restart the trade from the beginning.
6. **Repurchasing**: The user can repurchase the trade if it hits a predetermined profit or loss percentage, closing a portion of the trade and reopening it at a lower position size.
7. **End Cycle at % Gain**: The user can set a stage to execute the process of closing both trades and reopening until the cycle count is finished, based on a set percentage gain.

These operational steps provide a general outline of the trading process, although specific steps may vary depending on the user's settings and the platform's features.

data.message: Appears to have trades not closing as per the MM settings. Any thoughts or suggestions on this? Although upon refresh there is an error “Cannot Read...”

response.answer:
Based on the provided context, it seems like the trades may not be closing as per the Money Management (MM) settings due to several possible reasons. Here are a few potential explanations and suggestions:

1. **Enable Trade Hedging not set to “Yes”**: Make sure that "Enable Trade Hedging" is set to "Yes" in the settings, as this is a requirement for the hedge trade button to be visible and for trades to be opened on both sides in the same currency.

2. **Incorrect trade size setup**: Ensure that the trade size setup is correctly configured and that it is not causing the trade to not close as per the MM settings.

3. **Stage not set to 100% close**: Check that the stage is set to 100% close, as this is a requirement for the trade to close automatically when the profit is reached.

4. **MM setting stages (check box) not checked**: Ensure that the MM setting stages (check box) is checked, as this is required to execute the process.

5. **Error upon refresh**: The error "Cannot Read..." upon refresh could be due to the "Wait for Close Signal for Trading View" option being selected. Try changing this option to "Close My Trade by Profits Karbon Advanced Management" and see if the issue is resolved.

If none of these suggestions resolve the issue, it would be helpful to have more information about the specific error messages and trade configurations.

data.message: How do limit orders work in trading?

response.answer:
Limit orders are not explicitly discussed in the provided documents. However, I can provide general information about limit orders.

A limit order is an order to buy or sell a security at a specific price or better. It allows you to specify a maximum price you are willing to pay (for a buy order) or a minimum price you are willing to receive (for a sell order). Limit orders are used to execute trades at a favorable price and can be set to buy or sell a security at a specific price or better.

In the context of trading platforms like Karbon, limit orders can be used to automate trading decisions based on predefined conditions, such as price levels. However, the specific implementation and usage of limit orders on Karbon are not discussed in the provided documents.

For more information on limit orders and their usage on trading platforms, I recommend consulting additional resources or the official documentation of your trading platform.

Introduction
1.1.Purpose
This platform facilitates effortless trading by allowing users to establish personalized settings, thereby enabling trades to be executed
automatically and requiring minimal human intervention. This platform could potentially assist in closing trades automatically when they
reach a profitable point. This streamlined approach ensures a user-friendly experience that stands out from traditional trading platforms
1.2.What is Trading
Trading is the buying and selling of financial instruments in order to make a profit. These instruments range from a variety of assets
assigned a financial value that can go up or down. Trading involves vigorous participation in the financial markets compared to
investing, which works on a buy-and-hold strategy. The success of trading is dependent on the ability of a trader to be profitable over a
period of time.
A trader is a person who gets involved in buying and selling a financial asset in any financial market. He or she can buy or sell either for
himself/herself or on behalf of another individual or institution. The main difference between an investor and a trader is the duration for
which he or she holds on to the asset.
A trader is a person who engages in the short-term purchasing and selling of equity either for an institution or for themselves.
1.3.What is a Candlestick
A candle stick is a type of price chart used in technical analysis that displays the high, low, open, and closing prices of a security for a
specific period.
wherein each candlestick details a single day’s trading. It has three essential features:
The body, which represents the open-to-close range
The wick, or shadow, that indicates the intra-day high and low

data.message: What are the techniques for using a Candle Indicator in trading?

response.answer:
Based on the provided context, the techniques for using a Candle Indicator in trading include:

1. **Recognizing Bullish, Bearish, and Neutral Pressure**: The Candle Indicator paints each candle green, red, or blue depending on whether the buy/sell pressure for that candle is bullish, bearish, or neutral.
2. **Identifying Buying and Selling Pressure**: When the directional movement index indicator shows more buying pressure than selling pressure, the candle will appear lime green, indicating bullish buying pressure. When it shows more selling pressure than buying pressure, the candle will appear red, indicating bearish selling pressure.
3. **Using Color Changes to Pinpoint Reversals**: The color changes can be used to see if there is more buying or selling pressure, helping to pinpoint reversals and understand current market buying.
4. **Waiting for Opposite Color to Enter or Exit Positions**: It is recommended to wait to enter or exit positions until the candles turn the opposite color.
5. **Using Candlestick Patterns**: Candlestick patterns can be used to recognize major support and resistance levels, providing insight into the balance between buying and selling pressures.

By using these techniques, traders can gain a better understanding of market trends and make more informed trading decisions.

End cycle at % gain
In this scenario, after opening the latest trade in hedge mode, we record the latest wallet balance, and the user can define a stage to
execute this process by using MM setting stages (check box). The user can enter a % value using the dropdown menu, and we check
after the selected stage hits; the profit of that hedge trade at the beginning, if the profit is => wallet_balance * selected_percentage,
both trades will close and reopen until the cycle count is finished. 0% means this feature is inactive at the time. 
Hedge trade PnL cycle count 
The user can define the cycle count by this setting; that means if a hedge trade is closed with a profit (after user-defined stage using
checkBox), it triggers a new hedge trade pair. The user can define using this setting how many times it needs to run; after the cycle
count ends, no hedge trade is open for that pair. 
Hedge Trade All close 
This is a trade action type with a 100% close; users cannot set any stages after this stage set. and also it can be set in a combine mode,
split mode, or positive and negative side. If the hedge trade hit this stage, both trades are closing at the moment. that close, not
calculate profit gain

response.answer:
It seems there is a small typo in your question. I'm assuming you meant to ask "what is Karbon".

Karbon is a platform that facilitates effortless trading by allowing users to establish personalized settings, thereby enabling trades to be executed automatically and requiring minimal human intervention.
response.context:
Introduction
1.1.Purpose
This platform facilitates effortless trading by allowing users to establish personalized settings, thereby enabling trades to be executed
automatically and requiring minimal human intervention. This platform could potentially assist in closing trades automatically when they
reach a profitable point. This streamlined approach ensures a user-friendly experience that stands out from traditional trading platforms
1.2.What is Trading
Trading is the buying and selling of financial instruments in order to make a profit. These instruments range from a variety of assets
assigned a financial value that can go up or down. Trading involves vigorous participation in the financial markets compared to
investing, which works on a buy-and-hold strategy. The success of trading is dependent on the ability of a trader to be profitable over a
period of time.
A trader is a person who gets involved in buying and selling a financial asset in any financial market. He or she can buy or sell either for
himself/herself or on behalf of another individual or institution. The main difference between an investor and a trader is the duration for
which he or she holds on to the asset.
A trader is a person who engages in the short-term purchasing and selling of equity either for an institution or for themselves.
1.3.What is a Candlestick
A candle stick is a type of price chart used in technical analysis that displays the high, low, open, and closing prices of a security for a
specific period.
wherein each candlestick details a single day’s trading. It has three essential features:
The body, which represents the open-to-close range
The wick, or shadow, that indicates the intra-day high and low

This real body represents the price range between the open and close of that day's trading. When the real body is filled in or black (also
red), it means the close was lower than the open. If the real body is white (or green), the close was higher than the open.
1.4.What is a Candle Indicator
This indicator paints each candle green, red, or blue depending on whether the buy/sell pressure for that candle is bullish, bearish, or
neutral.
1.5.How to Use Indicator
When the directional movement index indicator shows more buying pressure than selling pressure, the candle will appear lime green.
This indicates bullish buying pressure. When the directional movement index indicator shows more selling pressure than buying
pressure, the candle will appear red. This indicates bearish selling pressure. When the directional movement index indicator shows the
same amount of buy and sell pressure, the candle will appear blue. This indicates neutral buy/sell pressure. 8 Use the color changes to
see if there is more buying or selling to pinpoint reversals and understand current market buying. Wait to enter or exit positions until the
candles turn the opposite color.

Assume you have $500 in your trading account, you configure the trade to open with 1% of wallet balance, the starting amount of the
trade is $5, with 20x leverage, the total position size is equal to 100%, and with the current market price, you can buy 0.001 BTC for $100.
In bybit, the minimum close/open quantity in BTC is 0.001 BTC (tick size). that minimum close/open quantity is different for every pair. In
this configuration, the stage is set as 50% close, which is equal to 0.0005 BTC. In this scenario, bybit rounded the value to 0.001 because
of tick size; in that case, trade is closed 100% from the bybit side.

response.answer:
Investing on the Karbon platform involves the following steps:

1. Register an account on the Karbon platform.
2. Create an API key on a supported exchange, such as Bitget or Bybit.
3. Set up your account settings, including enabling trade hedging and configuring your API key.
4. Add funds to your sub-account via the navigation bar.
5. Open trades in the trading platform, and then add and sync them with the platform.

Additionally, you can also use features such as Minimum Profit Target, Repurchase, and Reset after Swing to manage your trades and maximize your profits.

Please note that trading involves risk, and it's essential to take appropriate risk management steps to avoid losses.

1.6.How does Trading Work
When trading, the user profit if the market price moves in the same direction as the user’s speculation; however, if it takes the opposite
direction, the user incur a loss. It’s important to note that trading is inherently risky and could lose more than expected if don’t take the
appropriate risk management steps. Trading happens between two parties and often involves a dealer network. No central, physical
location only a virtual network of participants. Timings 24/7. Contracts are Customized. Counterparty risk, assets can be more volatile,
and can be traded on leverage, which means there’s a risk of losing more than the deposit

Ex: In this stage, the trade will change the leverage type to cross 10x at negative 50% PnL.
Repurchase
Repurchase is a feature that allows users to repurchase the trade. If the trade PnL% hits that given value, the action will trigger
immediately.
Ex: In this stage, the trade will repurchase 50% of the opened trade at negative 50% PnL.
Reset after Swing
In Karbon platform We can use 2 deferent methods in hedge mode.
Reset after Swing
In this mode, users can create a hedge trade that will be reset its stages after hit opposite side 1st stage For a example : if trade is
at P4 stage and going down to hit N.1. after hit N.1 positive stages reset and it became P.entry stage. If negative stage is
repurchase, that quantity will be dropped with small profit at latest entry price. For that It create TP order in Bybit
No reset after Swing
In this mode, users can create a hedge trade that will not be reset its stages after hit opposite side 1st stage For a example : if
trade is at P4 stage and going down to hit N.1. after hit N.1 positive stage remains P.4 stage.

1.6.How does Trading Work
When trading, the user profit if the market price moves in the same direction as the user’s speculation; however, if it takes the opposite
direction, the user incur a loss. It’s important to note that trading is inherently risky and could lose more than expected if don’t take the
appropriate risk management steps. Trading happens between two parties and often involves a dealer network. No central, physical
location only a virtual network of participants. Timings 24/7. Contracts are Customized. Counterparty risk, assets can be more volatile,
and can be traded on leverage, which means there’s a risk of losing more than the deposit

Introduction
1.1.Purpose
This platform facilitates effortless trading by allowing users to establish personalized settings, thereby enabling trades to be executed
automatically and requiring minimal human intervention. This platform could potentially assist in closing trades automatically when they
reach a profitable point. This streamlined approach ensures a user-friendly experience that stands out from traditional trading platforms
1.2.What is Trading
Trading is the buying and selling of financial instruments in order to make a profit. These instruments range from a variety of assets
assigned a financial value that can go up or down. Trading involves vigorous participation in the financial markets compared to
investing, which works on a buy-and-hold strategy. The success of trading is dependent on the ability of a trader to be profitable over a
period of time.
A trader is a person who gets involved in buying and selling a financial asset in any financial market. He or she can buy or sell either for
himself/herself or on behalf of another individual or institution. The main difference between an investor and a trader is the duration for
which he or she holds on to the asset.
A trader is a person who engages in the short-term purchasing and selling of equity either for an institution or for themselves.
1.3.What is a Candlestick
A candle stick is a type of price chart used in technical analysis that displays the high, low, open, and closing prices of a security for a
specific period.
wherein each candlestick details a single day’s trading. It has three essential features:
The body, which represents the open-to-close range
The wick, or shadow, that indicates the intra-day high and low
Max No Of Trades(Long and Short)
Long 
Maximum number of open long trades means, the user is not allowed to open the long trades more than the selected number. If
the user tries to open more trades “Karbon blocked this trade due to a maximum number of running long trades” message will be
displayed
Shor t 
Maximum number of open short trades means, the user is not allowed to open the short trades more than the selected number. If
the user tries to open more trades “Karbon blocked this trade due to a maximum number of running short trades” message will be
displayed
Leverage
Leverage is the ability to control a large position with a small amount of capital. It is a double-edged sword that can magnify both gains
and losses. The leverage is the amount of money that a trader is willing to risk on a trade. It is important to set the leverage to a level
that is comfortable for the trader and that will not cause financial hardship if the trade is lost.
Leverage types

Tick Size Error
Assume you have $500 in your trading account, you configure the trade to open with 1% of wallet balance, the starting amount of the
trade is $5, with 20x leverage, the total position size is equal to 100%, and with the current market price, you can buy 0.001 BTC for $100.
In bybit, the minimum close/open quantity in BTC is 0.001 BTC (tick size). that minimum close/open quantity is different for every pair. In
this configuration, the stage is set as 50% close, which is equal to 0.0005 BTC. In this scenario, bybit rounded the value to 0.001 because
of tick size; in that case, trade is closed 100% from the bybit side. 
For more Info : Click Here

Repurchase
Repurchase is a feature that allows users to repurchase the trade. If the trade PnL% hits that given value, the action will trigger
immediately.
Ex: In this stage, the trade will repurchase 50% of the opened trade at negative 50% PnL.
Reset after Swing
In Karbon platform We can use 2 deferent methods in hedge mode.
Reset after Swing
In this mode, users can create a hedge trade that will be reset its stages after hit opposite side 1st stage For a example : if trade is
at P4 stage and going down to hit N.1. after hit N.1 positive stages reset and it became P.entry stage. If negative stage is
repurchase, that quantity will be dropped with small profit at latest entry price. For that It create TP order in Bybit
No reset after Swing
In this mode, users can create a hedge trade that will not be reset its stages after hit opposite side 1st stage For a example : if
trade is at P4 stage and going down to hit N.1. after hit N.1 positive stage remains P.4 stage.

Reset after Swing
In Karbon platform We can use 2 deferent methods in hedge mode.
Reset after Swing
In this mode, users can create a hedge trade that will be reset its stages after hit opposite side 1st stage For a example : if trade is
at P4 stage and going down to hit N.1. after hit N.1 positive stages reset and it became P.entry stage. If negative stage is
repurchase, that quantity will be dropped with small profit at latest entry price. For that It create TP order in Bybit
No reset after Swing
In this mode, users can create a hedge trade that will not be reset its stages after hit opposite side 1st stage For a example : if
trade is at P4 stage and going down to hit N.1. after hit N.1 positive stage remains P.4 stage.

Introduction
1.1.Purpose
This platform facilitates effortless trading by allowing users to establish personalized settings, thereby enabling trades to be executed
automatically and requiring minimal human intervention. This platform could potentially assist in closing trades automatically when they
reach a profitable point. This streamlined approach ensures a user-friendly experience that stands out from traditional trading platforms
1.2.What is Trading
Trading is the buying and selling of financial instruments in order to make a profit. These instruments range from a variety of assets
assigned a financial value that can go up or down. Trading involves vigorous participation in the financial markets compared to
investing, which works on a buy-and-hold strategy. The success of trading is dependent on the ability of a trader to be profitable over a
period of time.
A trader is a person who gets involved in buying and selling a financial asset in any financial market. He or she can buy or sell either for
himself/herself or on behalf of another individual or institution. The main difference between an investor and a trader is the duration for
which he or she holds on to the asset.
A trader is a person who engages in the short-term purchasing and selling of equity either for an institution or for themselves.
1.3.What is a Candlestick
A candle stick is a type of price chart used in technical analysis that displays the high, low, open, and closing prices of a security for a
specific period.
wherein each candlestick details a single day’s trading. It has three essential features:
The body, which represents the open-to-close range
The wick, or shadow, that indicates the intra-day high and low
1.6.How does Trading Work
When trading, the user profit if the market price moves in the same direction as the user’s speculation; however, if it takes the opposite
direction, the user incur a loss. It’s important to note that trading is inherently risky and could lose more than expected if don’t take the
appropriate risk management steps. Trading happens between two parties and often involves a dealer network. No central, physical
location only a virtual network of participants. Timings 24/7. Contracts are Customized. Counterparty risk, assets can be more volatile,
and can be traded on leverage, which means there’s a risk of losing more than the deposit

https://avishkanirmitha.github.io/karbon-doc/ 3/33
End cycle at % gain
In this scenario, after opening the latest trade in hedge mode, we record the latest wallet balance, and the user can define a stage to
execute this process by using MM setting stages (check box). The user can enter a % value using the dropdown menu, and we check
after the selected stage hits; the profit of that hedge trade at the beginning, if the profit is => wallet_balance * selected_percentage,
both trades will close and reopen until the cycle count is finished. 0% means this feature is inactive at the time. 
Hedge trade PnL cycle count 
The user can define the cycle count by this setting; that means if a hedge trade is closed with a profit (after user-defined stage using
checkBox), it triggers a new hedge trade pair. The user can define using this setting how many times it needs to run; after the cycle
count ends, no hedge trade is open for that pair. 
Hedge Trade All close 
This is a trade action type with a 100% close; users cannot set any stages after this stage set. and also it can be set in a combine mode,
split mode, or positive and negative side. If the hedge trade hit this stage, both trades are closing at the moment. that close, not
calculate profit gain

response.answer:
Based on the provided documents, here's what I found about Bitget exchange:

1. **Creating an account on Bitget:** You can create an account on Bitget through email or phone number sign up. After creating an account, you need to complete the verification requirements by dragging a slider on a verification page.
2. **Accessing Bitget:** You can access Bitget through the Bitget app, website, or desktop application available for iOS, Android, and browser-based websites, as well as a desktop application for Mac and Windows.
3. **API Key on Bitget:** To create an API key on Bitget, you need to click on the link to enter your account's settings page, perform a login if prompted, or click on the human icon on the top right corner of your trading page. Then, click on the "create API" button.
4. **Bitget Accounts:** Bitget offers various account types, including Default, Admin, User, Lab User, Elite User, Pro User, and Pro + User. Each account type has its own features and benefits.
5. **Exchange Platforms:** Bitget is one of the exchange platforms that users can connect with their Karbon account. Other exchange platforms mentioned include Bybit and Binance.
6. **Bitget Features:** Some specific features mentioned in the documents related to Bitget include Minimum Profit Target, where the trade is closed automatically when the profit is reached, and Enable Trade Hedging, which allows users to open trades on both sides in the same currency.

Please note that these are just the findings based on the provided documents, and there might be more features and information available on the actual Bitget platform.

response.answer:
To gain in Karbon, you can try the following methods mentioned in the documents:

1. **End Cycle at % Gain**: After opening the latest trade in hedge mode, you can record the latest wallet balance and define a stage to execute this process using MM setting stages. If the profit of the hedge trade at the beginning is greater than or equal to the wallet balance multiplied by the selected percentage, both trades will close and reopen until the cycle count is finished.

2. **Hedge Trade PnL Cycle Count**: You can define the cycle count using this setting. If a hedge trade is closed with a profit (after a user-defined stage using a checkbox), it triggers a new hedge trade pair. You can define how many times it needs to run; after the cycle count ends, no hedge trade is open for that pair.

3. **Long and Short**: The documents also mention the concept of long and short trades. You can consider opening long trades when the market is expected to rise and short trades when the market is expected to fall.

4. **Leverage**: The documents emphasize the importance of setting the leverage to a level that is comfortable for the trader and that will not cause financial hardship if the trade is lost. Leverage can be used to control a large position with a small amount of capital.

Please note that trading carries risks, and there are no guarantees of gains. It's essential to understand the concepts and risks involved before making any trades.

data.message: Appears to have trades not closing as per the MM settings. Any thoughts or suggestions on this? Although upon refresh there is an error “Cannot Read...”

response.answer:
Based on the provided context, it seems like there are a few possible reasons why trades are not closing as per the Money Management (MM) settings:

1. **Validation Error**: The error "Cannot Read..." might be due to a missing or invalid configuration in the TradingView template or an error in the input parameters. Make sure all fields are correctly filled and the template is properly configured.

2. **Validate Stages**: Ensure that you have only one stage for trades selected to wait for a closing signal from TradingView. If you have multiple stages, they might not be closing as expected.

3. **MM Settings**: Double-check your MM settings in the KarbonDX platform to ensure that they are correctly configured and in sync with your TradingVIEW template.

4. **Tick Size**: Be aware of the tick size for each pair, as mentioned in the documentation (e.g., 0.001 BTC for BTC). This can affect the trade closing logic.

To troubleshoot the issue, I recommend checking the logs and configurations, validating the stages, and ensuring that your MM settings are correctly set up. If the problem persists, consider reaching out to the Karbon support team for further assistance.

Tick Size Error
Assume you have $500 in your trading account, you configure the trade to open with 1% of wallet balance, the starting amount of the
trade is $5, with 20x leverage, the total position size is equal to 100%, and with the current market price, you can buy 0.001 BTC for $100.
In bybit, the minimum close/open quantity in BTC is 0.001 BTC (tick size). that minimum close/open quantity is different for every pair. In
this configuration, the stage is set as 50% close, which is equal to 0.0005 BTC. In this scenario, bybit rounded the value to 0.001 because
of tick size; in that case, trade is closed 100% from the bybit side.

1.6.How does Trading Work
When trading, the user profit if the market price moves in the same direction as the user’s speculation; however, if it takes the opposite
direction, the user incur a loss. It’s important to note that trading is inherently risky and could lose more than expected if don’t take the
appropriate risk management steps. Trading happens between two parties and often involves a dealer network. No central, physical
location only a virtual network of participants. Timings 24/7. Contracts are Customized. Counterparty risk, assets can be more volatile,
and can be traded on leverage, which means there’s a risk of losing more than the deposit

https://avishkanirmitha.github.io/karbon-doc/ 3/33
Introduction
1.1.Purpose
This platform facilitates effortless trading by allowing users to establish personalized settings, thereby enabling trades to be executed
automatically and requiring minimal human intervention. This platform could potentially assist in closing trades automatically when they
reach a profitable point. This streamlined approach ensures a user-friendly experience that stands out from traditional trading platforms
1.2.What is Trading
Trading is the buying and selling of financial instruments in order to make a profit. These instruments range from a variety of assets
assigned a financial value that can go up or down. Trading involves vigorous participation in the financial markets compared to
investing, which works on a buy-and-hold strategy. The success of trading is dependent on the ability of a trader to be profitable over a
period of time.
A trader is a person who gets involved in buying and selling a financial asset in any financial market. He or she can buy or sell either for
himself/herself or on behalf of another individual or institution. The main difference between an investor and a trader is the duration for
which he or she holds on to the asset.
A trader is a person who engages in the short-term purchasing and selling of equity either for an institution or for themselves.
1.3.What is a Candlestick
A candle stick is a type of price chart used in technical analysis that displays the high, low, open, and closing prices of a security for a
specific period.
wherein each candlestick details a single day’s trading. It has three essential features:
The body, which represents the open-to-close range
The wick, or shadow, that indicates the intra-day high and low
Max No Of Trades(Long and Short)
Long 
Maximum number of open long trades means, the user is not allowed to open the long trades more than the selected number. If
the user tries to open more trades “Karbon blocked this trade due to a maximum number of running long trades” message will be
displayed
Shor t 
Maximum number of open short trades means, the user is not allowed to open the short trades more than the selected number. If
the user tries to open more trades “Karbon blocked this trade due to a maximum number of running short trades” message will be
displayed
Leverage
Leverage is the ability to control a large position with a small amount of capital. It is a double-edged sword that can magnify both gains
and losses. The leverage is the amount of money that a trader is willing to risk on a trade. It is important to set the leverage to a level
that is comfortable for the trader and that will not cause financial hardship if the trade is lost.
Leverage types

response.answer:
To create an API key on Bybit, follow these steps:

1. Click on the link to enter your account's settings page. Perform a login if prompted.
2. Alternatively, you can click the human icon on the top right corner of your trading page, go to "Subaccounts" then click "Management" in the created sub account.
3. Click on 'API Management' page.
4. Click on 'Create New Key' located on the right side of the 'API Management' page.
5. Click system-generated API keys.
6. A pop-out window will appear. Please configure your API key according to your trading needs.

Introduction
1.1.Purpose
This platform facilitates effortless trading by allowing users to establish personalized settings, thereby enabling trades to be executed
automatically and requiring minimal human intervention. This platform could potentially assist in closing trades automatically when they
reach a profitable point. This streamlined approach ensures a user-friendly experience that stands out from traditional trading platforms
1.2.What is Trading
Trading is the buying and selling of financial instruments in order to make a profit. These instruments range from a variety of assets
assigned a financial value that can go up or down. Trading involves vigorous participation in the financial markets compared to
investing, which works on a buy-and-hold strategy. The success of trading is dependent on the ability of a trader to be profitable over a
period of time.
A trader is a person who gets involved in buying and selling a financial asset in any financial market. He or she can buy or sell either for
himself/herself or on behalf of another individual or institution. The main difference between an investor and a trader is the duration for
which he or she holds on to the asset.
A trader is a person who engages in the short-term purchasing and selling of equity either for an institution or for themselves.
1.3.What is a Candlestick
A candle stick is a type of price chart used in technical analysis that displays the high, low, open, and closing prices of a security for a
specific period.
wherein each candlestick details a single day’s trading. It has three essential features:
The body, which represents the open-to-close range
The wick, or shadow, that indicates the intra-day high and low
Max No Of Trades(Long and Short)
Long 
Maximum number of open long trades means, the user is not allowed to open the long trades more than the selected number. If
the user tries to open more trades “Karbon blocked this trade due to a maximum number of running long trades” message will be
displayed
Shor t 
Maximum number of open short trades means, the user is not allowed to open the short trades more than the selected number. If
the user tries to open more trades “Karbon blocked this trade due to a maximum number of running short trades” message will be
displayed
Leverage
Leverage is the ability to control a large position with a small amount of capital. It is a double-edged sword that can magnify both gains
and losses. The leverage is the amount of money that a trader is willing to risk on a trade. It is important to set the leverage to a level
that is comfortable for the trader and that will not cause financial hardship if the trade is lost.
Leverage types

this configuration, the stage is set as 50% close, which is equal to 0.0005 BTC. In this scenario, bybit rounded the value to 0.001 because

Introduction
1.1.Purpose
This platform facilitates effortless trading by allowing users to establish personalized settings, thereby enabling trades to be executed
automatically and requiring minimal human intervention. This platform could potentially assist in closing trades automatically when they
reach a profitable point. This streamlined approach ensures a user-friendly experience that stands out from traditional trading platforms
1.2.What is Trading
Trading is the buying and selling of financial instruments in order to make a profit. These instruments range from a variety of assets
assigned a financial value that can go up or down. Trading involves vigorous participation in the financial markets compared to
investing, which works on a buy-and-hold strategy. The success of trading is dependent on the ability of a trader to be profitable over a
period of time.
A trader is a person who gets involved in buying and selling a financial asset in any financial market. He or she can buy or sell either for
himself/herself or on behalf of another individual or institution. The main difference between an investor and a trader is the duration for
which he or she holds on to the asset.
A trader is a person who engages in the short-term purchasing and selling of equity either for an institution or for themselves.
1.3.What is a Candlestick
A candle stick is a type of price chart used in technical analysis that displays the high, low, open, and closing prices of a security for a
specific period.
wherein each candlestick details a single day’s trading. It has three essential features:
The body, which represents the open-to-close range
The wick, or shadow, that indicates the intra-day high and low
pattern indicators that are available on the platform. Essentially, the strategy differs from the CandlePatternsMultiple strategy only by
calculated indicator count and by the way the list of indicators gets compiled.
This real body represents the price range between the open and close of that day's trading. When the real body is filled in or black (also
red), it means the close was lower than the open. If the real body is white (or green), the close was higher than the open.
1.4.What is a Candle Indicator
This indicator paints each candle green, red, or blue depending on whether the buy/sell pressure for that candle is bullish, bearish, or
neutral.
1.5.How to Use Indicator
When the directional movement index indicator shows more buying pressure than selling pressure, the candle will appear lime green.
This indicates bullish buying pressure. When the directional movement index indicator shows more selling pressure than buying
pressure, the candle will appear red. This indicates bearish selling pressure. When the directional movement index indicator shows the
same amount of buy and sell pressure, the candle will appear blue. This indicates neutral buy/sell pressure. 8 Use the color changes to
see if there is more buying or selling to pinpoint reversals and understand current market buying. Wait to enter or exit positions until the
candles turn the opposite color.

Repurchase
Repurchase is a feature that allows users to repurchase the trade. If the trade PnL% hits that given value, the action will trigger
immediately.
Ex: In this stage, the trade will repurchase 50% of the opened trade at negative 50% PnL.
Reset after Swing
In Karbon platform We can use 2 deferent methods in hedge mode.
Reset after Swing
In this mode, users can create a hedge trade that will be reset its stages after hit opposite side 1st stage For a example : if trade is
at P4 stage and going down to hit N.1. after hit N.1 positive stages reset and it became P.entry stage. If negative stage is
repurchase, that quantity will be dropped with small profit at latest entry price. For that It create TP order in Bybit
No reset after Swing
In this mode, users can create a hedge trade that will not be reset its stages after hit opposite side 1st stage For a example : if
trade is at P4 stage and going down to hit N.1. after hit N.1 positive stage remains P.4 stage.

End cycle at % gain
In this scenario, after opening the latest trade in hedge mode, we record the latest wallet balance, and the user can define a stage to
execute this process by using MM setting stages (check box). The user can enter a % value using the dropdown menu, and we check
after the selected stage hits; the profit of that hedge trade at the beginning, if the profit is => wallet_balance * selected_percentage,
both trades will close and reopen until the cycle count is finished. 0% means this feature is inactive at the time. 
Hedge trade PnL cycle count 
The user can define the cycle count by this setting; that means if a hedge trade is closed with a profit (after user-defined stage using
checkBox), it triggers a new hedge trade pair. The user can define using this setting how many times it needs to run; after the cycle
count ends, no hedge trade is open for that pair. 
Hedge Trade All close 
This is a trade action type with a 100% close; users cannot set any stages after this stage set. and also it can be set in a combine mode,
split mode, or positive and negative side. If the hedge trade hit this stage, both trades are closing at the moment. that close, not

Tick Size Error
Assume you have $500 in your trading account, you configure the trade to open with 1% of wallet balance, the starting amount of the
trade is $5, with 20x leverage, the total position size is equal to 100%, and with the current market price, you can buy 0.001 BTC for $100.
In bybit, the minimum close/open quantity in BTC is 0.001 BTC (tick size). that minimum close/open quantity is different for every pair. In
this configuration, the stage is set as 50% close, which is equal to 0.0005 BTC. In this scenario, bybit rounded the value to 0.001 because
of tick size; in that case, trade is closed 100% from the bybit side.

Introduction
1.1.Purpose
This platform facilitates effortless trading by allowing users to establish personalized settings, thereby enabling trades to be executed
automatically and requiring minimal human intervention. This platform could potentially assist in closing trades automatically when they
reach a profitable point. This streamlined approach ensures a user-friendly experience that stands out from traditional trading platforms
1.2.What is Trading
Trading is the buying and selling of financial instruments in order to make a profit. These instruments range from a variety of assets
assigned a financial value that can go up or down. Trading involves vigorous participation in the financial markets compared to
investing, which works on a buy-and-hold strategy. The success of trading is dependent on the ability of a trader to be profitable over a
period of time.
A trader is a person who gets involved in buying and selling a financial asset in any financial market. He or she can buy or sell either for
himself/herself or on behalf of another individual or institution. The main difference between an investor and a trader is the duration for
which he or she holds on to the asset.
A trader is a person who engages in the short-term purchasing and selling of equity either for an institution or for themselves.
1.3.What is a Candlestick
A candle stick is a type of price chart used in technical analysis that displays the high, low, open, and closing prices of a security for a
specific period.
wherein each candlestick details a single day’s trading. It has three essential features:
The body, which represents the open-to-close range
The wick, or shadow, that indicates the intra-day high and low

1.6.How does Trading Work
When trading, the user profit if the market price moves in the same direction as the user’s speculation; however, if it takes the opposite
direction, the user incur a loss. It’s important to note that trading is inherently risky and could lose more than expected if don’t take the
appropriate risk management steps. Trading happens between two parties and often involves a dealer network. No central, physical
location only a virtual network of participants. Timings 24/7. Contracts are Customized. Counterparty risk, assets can be more volatile,
and can be traded on leverage, which means there’s a risk of losing more than the deposit

1.4.What is a Candle Indicator
This indicator paints each candle green, red, or blue depending on whether the buy/sell pressure for that candle is bullish, bearish, or
neutral.
1.5.How to Use Indicator
When the directional movement index indicator shows more buying pressure than selling pressure, the candle will appear lime green.
This indicates bullish buying pressure. When the directional movement index indicator shows more selling pressure than buying
pressure, the candle will appear red. This indicates bearish selling pressure. When the directional movement index indicator shows the
same amount of buy and sell pressure, the candle will appear blue. This indicates neutral buy/sell pressure. 8 Use the color changes to
see if there is more buying or selling to pinpoint reversals and understand current market buying. Wait to enter or exit positions until the
candles turn the opposite color.

they want. This feature is only for a selected user set. If you cannot see this. You are not in that user list.

Close Trade
Change Leverage

Repurcherse
Close Trades
In this take action, users can define a profit or loss percentage and position size that need to close. If the trade PnL% hits that given
value, the action will trigger immediately.
Responsive image

Change Leverage
Change leverage is a feature that allows users to change the leverage of the trade. If the trade PnL% hits that given value, the action will
trigger immediately.
Ex: In this stage, the trade will change the leverage to isolated 10x at negative 50% PnL.
Change Leverage Type
Change leverage type is a feature that allows users to change the leverage type of the trade. If the trade PnL% hits that given value, the
action will trigger immediately.

Ex: In this stage, the trade will change the leverage type to cross 10x at negative 50% PnL.
Repurchase
Repurchase is a feature that allows users to repurchase the trade. If the trade PnL% hits that given value, the action will trigger
immediately.
Ex: In this stage, the trade will repurchase 50% of the opened trade at negative 50% PnL.
Reset after Swing
In Karbon platform We can use 2 deferent methods in hedge mode.
Reset after Swing
In this mode, users can create a hedge trade that will be reset its stages after hit opposite side 1st stage For a example : if trade is
at P4 stage and going down to hit N.1. after hit N.1 positive stages reset and it became P.entry stage. If negative stage is
repurchase, that quantity will be dropped with small profit at latest entry price. For that It create TP order in Bybit
No reset after Swing
In this mode, users can create a hedge trade that will not be reset its stages after hit opposite side 1st stage For a example : if
trade is at P4 stage and going down to hit N.1. after hit N.1 positive stage remains P.4 stage.

Tick Size Error
Assume you have $500 in your trading account, you configure the trade to open with 1% of wallet balance, the starting amount of the
trade is $5, with 20x leverage, the total position size is equal to 100%, and with the current market price, you can buy 0.001 BTC for $100.
In bybit, the minimum close/open quantity in BTC is 0.001 BTC (tick size). that minimum close/open quantity is different for every pair. In
this configuration, the stage is set as 50% close, which is equal to 0.0005 BTC. In this scenario, bybit rounded the value to 0.001 because
of tick size; in that case, trade is closed 100% from the bybit side.

https://avishkanirmitha.github.io/karbon-doc/ 20/33
End cycle at % gain
In this scenario, after opening the latest trade in hedge mode, we record the latest wallet balance, and the user can define a stage to
execute this process by using MM setting stages (check box). The user can enter a % value using the dropdown menu, and we check
after the selected stage hits; the profit of that hedge trade at the beginning, if the profit is => wallet_balance * selected_percentage,
both trades will close and reopen until the cycle count is finished. 0% means this feature is inactive at the time. 
Hedge trade PnL cycle count 
The user can define the cycle count by this setting; that means if a hedge trade is closed with a profit (after user-defined stage using
checkBox), it triggers a new hedge trade pair. The user can define using this setting how many times it needs to run; after the cycle
count ends, no hedge trade is open for that pair. 
Hedge Trade All close 
This is a trade action type with a 100% close; users cannot set any stages after this stage set. and also it can be set in a combine mode,
split mode, or positive and negative side. If the hedge trade hit this stage, both trades are closing at the moment. that close, not
calculate profit gain

Introduction
1.1.Purpose
This platform facilitates effortless trading by allowing users to establish personalized settings, thereby enabling trades to be executed
automatically and requiring minimal human intervention. This platform could potentially assist in closing trades automatically when they
reach a profitable point. This streamlined approach ensures a user-friendly experience that stands out from traditional trading platforms
1.2.What is Trading
Trading is the buying and selling of financial instruments in order to make a profit. These instruments range from a variety of assets
assigned a financial value that can go up or down. Trading involves vigorous participation in the financial markets compared to
investing, which works on a buy-and-hold strategy. The success of trading is dependent on the ability of a trader to be profitable over a
period of time.
A trader is a person who gets involved in buying and selling a financial asset in any financial market. He or she can buy or sell either for
himself/herself or on behalf of another individual or institution. The main difference between an investor and a trader is the duration for
which he or she holds on to the asset.
A trader is a person who engages in the short-term purchasing and selling of equity either for an institution or for themselves.
1.3.What is a Candlestick
A candle stick is a type of price chart used in technical analysis that displays the high, low, open, and closing prices of a security for a
specific period.
wherein each candlestick details a single day’s trading. It has three essential features:
The body, which represents the open-to-close range
The wick, or shadow, that indicates the intra-day high and low

End cycle at % gain
In this scenario, after opening the latest trade in hedge mode, we record the latest wallet balance, and the user can define a stage to
execute this process by using MM setting stages (check box). The user can enter a % value using the dropdown menu, and we check
after the selected stage hits; the profit of that hedge trade at the beginning, if the profit is => wallet_balance * selected_percentage,
both trades will close and reopen until the cycle count is finished. 0% means this feature is inactive at the time. 
Hedge trade PnL cycle count 
The user can define the cycle count by this setting; that means if a hedge trade is closed with a profit (after user-defined stage using
checkBox), it triggers a new hedge trade pair. The user can define using this setting how many times it needs to run; after the cycle
count ends, no hedge trade is open for that pair. 
Hedge Trade All close 
This is a trade action type with a 100% close; users cannot set any stages after this stage set. and also it can be set in a combine mode,
split mode, or positive and negative side. If the hedge trade hit this stage, both trades are closing at the moment. that close, not
calculate profit gain

Introduction
1.1.Purpose
This platform facilitates effortless trading by allowing users to establish personalized settings, thereby enabling trades to be executed
automatically and requiring minimal human intervention. This platform could potentially assist in closing trades automatically when they
reach a profitable point. This streamlined approach ensures a user-friendly experience that stands out from traditional trading platforms
1.2.What is Trading
Trading is the buying and selling of financial instruments in order to make a profit. These instruments range from a variety of assets
assigned a financial value that can go up or down. Trading involves vigorous participation in the financial markets compared to
investing, which works on a buy-and-hold strategy. The success of trading is dependent on the ability of a trader to be profitable over a
period of time.
A trader is a person who gets involved in buying and selling a financial asset in any financial market. He or she can buy or sell either for
himself/herself or on behalf of another individual or institution. The main difference between an investor and a trader is the duration for
which he or she holds on to the asset.
A trader is a person who engages in the short-term purchasing and selling of equity either for an institution or for themselves.
1.3.What is a Candlestick
A candle stick is a type of price chart used in technical analysis that displays the high, low, open, and closing prices of a security for a
specific period.
wherein each candlestick details a single day’s trading. It has three essential features:
The body, which represents the open-to-close range
The wick, or shadow, that indicates the intra-day high and low

Repurchase
Repurchase is a feature that allows users to repurchase the trade. If the trade PnL% hits that given value, the action will trigger
immediately.
Ex: In this stage, the trade will repurchase 50% of the opened trade at negative 50% PnL.
Reset after Swing
In Karbon platform We can use 2 deferent methods in hedge mode.
Reset after Swing
In this mode, users can create a hedge trade that will be reset its stages after hit opposite side 1st stage For a example : if trade is
at P4 stage and going down to hit N.1. after hit N.1 positive stages reset and it became P.entry stage. If negative stage is
repurchase, that quantity will be dropped with small profit at latest entry price. For that It create TP order in Bybit
No reset after Swing
In this mode, users can create a hedge trade that will not be reset its stages after hit opposite side 1st stage For a example : if
trade is at P4 stage and going down to hit N.1. after hit N.1 positive stage remains P.4 stage.

Bybit is a cryptocurrency derivatives exchange where users can trade various cryptocurrencies with leverage. It provides features such as spot trading, futures trading, and margin trading. Bybit supports a variety of cryptocurrencies and offers various trading tools and services.

To create an account on Bybit, users can sign up through the official website or by connecting their Karbon account. The account type on Bybit is not explicitly mentioned in the provided context, but it is stated that Bybit is one of the exchange platforms supported by Karbon.

According to the Karbon User Guide, there are two ways to create a Bybit account: sign up by email or sign up by phone number. The account creation process involves filling in the required information and verifying the account through a verification code sent to the user's email or phone number.

In the context of Karbon, Bybit is integrated as a supported exchange platform, allowing users to connect their Bybit account to their Karbon account and manage their trading activities through the Karbon platform.

calculate profit gain

Repurchase

Reset after Swing
In Karbon platform We can use 2 deferent methods in hedge mode.
Reset after Swing
In this mode, users can create a hedge trade that will be reset its stages after hit opposite side 1st stage For a example : if trade is
at P4 stage and going down to hit N.1. after hit N.1 positive stages reset and it became P.entry stage. If negative stage is
repurchase, that quantity will be dropped with small profit at latest entry price. For that It create TP order in Bybit
No reset after Swing
In this mode, users can create a hedge trade that will not be reset its stages after hit opposite side 1st stage For a example : if
trade is at P4 stage and going down to hit N.1. after hit N.1 positive stage remains P.4 stage.

1.6.How does Trading Work
When trading, the user profit if the market price moves in the same direction as the user’s speculation; however, if it takes the opposite
direction, the user incur a loss. It’s important to note that trading is inherently risky and could lose more than expected if don’t take the
appropriate risk management steps. Trading happens between two parties and often involves a dealer network. No central, physical
location only a virtual network of participants. Timings 24/7. Contracts are Customized. Counterparty risk, assets can be more volatile,
and can be traded on leverage, which means there’s a risk of losing more than the deposit

Introduction
1.1.Purpose
This platform facilitates effortless trading by allowing users to establish personalized settings, thereby enabling trades to be executed
automatically and requiring minimal human intervention. This platform could potentially assist in closing trades automatically when they
reach a profitable point. This streamlined approach ensures a user-friendly experience that stands out from traditional trading platforms
1.2.What is Trading
Trading is the buying and selling of financial instruments in order to make a profit. These instruments range from a variety of assets
assigned a financial value that can go up or down. Trading involves vigorous participation in the financial markets compared to
investing, which works on a buy-and-hold strategy. The success of trading is dependent on the ability of a trader to be profitable over a
period of time.
A trader is a person who gets involved in buying and selling a financial asset in any financial market. He or she can buy or sell either for
himself/herself or on behalf of another individual or institution. The main difference between an investor and a trader is the duration for
which he or she holds on to the asset.
A trader is a person who engages in the short-term purchasing and selling of equity either for an institution or for themselves.
1.3.What is a Candlestick
A candle stick is a type of price chart used in technical analysis that displays the high, low, open, and closing prices of a security for a
specific period.
wherein each candlestick details a single day’s trading. It has three essential features:
The body, which represents the open-to-close range
The wick, or shadow, that indicates the intra-day high and low
Minimum Profit Target
Minimum profit target means, the trade is closed automatically when the profit is reached.
Enable Trade Hedging
In one-way mode, trade cannot be opened on both sides in the same currency. In hedge mode, trades can be opened on both sides in
the same currency. If Enable Trade Hedge in settings is “Yes” the hedge trade button will be visiblet

In one-way mode, trade cannot be opened on both sides in the same currency. In hedge mode, trades can be opened on both sides in

1.6.How does Trading Work
When trading, the user profit if the market price moves in the same direction as the user’s speculation; however, if it takes the opposite
direction, the user incur a loss. It’s important to note that trading is inherently risky and could lose more than expected if don’t take the
appropriate risk management steps. Trading happens between two parties and often involves a dealer network. No central, physical
location only a virtual network of participants. Timings 24/7. Contracts are Customized. Counterparty risk, assets can be more volatile,
and can be traded on leverage, which means there’s a risk of losing more than the deposit

https://avishkanirmitha.github.io/karbon-doc/ 3/33
End cycle at % gain
In this scenario, after opening the latest trade in hedge mode, we record the latest wallet balance, and the user can define a stage to
execute this process by using MM setting stages (check box). The user can enter a % value using the dropdown menu, and we check
after the selected stage hits; the profit of that hedge trade at the beginning, if the profit is => wallet_balance * selected_percentage,
both trades will close and reopen until the cycle count is finished. 0% means this feature is inactive at the time. 
Hedge trade PnL cycle count 
The user can define the cycle count by this setting; that means if a hedge trade is closed with a profit (after user-defined stage using
checkBox), it triggers a new hedge trade pair. The user can define using this setting how many times it needs to run; after the cycle
count ends, no hedge trade is open for that pair. 
Hedge Trade All close 
This is a trade action type with a 100% close; users cannot set any stages after this stage set. and also it can be set in a combine mode,
split mode, or positive and negative side. If the hedge trade hit this stage, both trades are closing at the moment. that close, not
calculate profit gain

Ex: In this stage, the trade will change the leverage type to cross 10x at negative 50% PnL.
Repurchase
Repurchase is a feature that allows users to repurchase the trade. If the trade PnL% hits that given value, the action will trigger
immediately.
Ex: In this stage, the trade will repurchase 50% of the opened trade at negative 50% PnL.
Reset after Swing
In Karbon platform We can use 2 deferent methods in hedge mode.
Reset after Swing
In this mode, users can create a hedge trade that will be reset its stages after hit opposite side 1st stage For a example : if trade is
at P4 stage and going down to hit N.1. after hit N.1 positive stages reset and it became P.entry stage. If negative stage is
repurchase, that quantity will be dropped with small profit at latest entry price. For that It create TP order in Bybit
No reset after Swing
In this mode, users can create a hedge trade that will not be reset its stages after hit opposite side 1st stage For a example : if
trade is at P4 stage and going down to hit N.1. after hit N.1 positive stage remains P.4 stage.

Tick Size Error
Assume you have $500 in your trading account, you configure the trade to open with 1% of wallet balance, the starting amount of the
trade is $5, with 20x leverage, the total position size is equal to 100%, and with the current market price, you can buy 0.001 BTC for $100.
In bybit, the minimum close/open quantity in BTC is 0.001 BTC (tick size). that minimum close/open quantity is different for every pair. In
this configuration, the stage is set as 50% close, which is equal to 0.0005 BTC. In this scenario, bybit rounded the value to 0.001 because
of tick size; in that case, trade is closed 100% from the bybit side. 
For more Info : Click Here

Create Stages for Trading View Trades
When the user has selected to wait for a closing signal from Tradingview, created trades must have only one stage. It will be a type 3
(close) stage and the call at percentage & the profit at percentage will be the user's trade size setup values (Long safety take profits %,
Long safety stop loss %, Short safety take profits %, short safety stop loss %). The value for that stage will always be 100%.
Advance Money Management Settings
Configuration of Advance Money Management Settings In the KarbonDX platform
Classic and Split Mode(With Positive)
Users can switch between combine mode and split mood using mentioned button below in karbon config page.
Classic Mode
When the combine mode is enabled, there are no positive stages; each negative stage has a user-defined take profit it self.Users
can add stages as many as they want.
Split Mode(with positive)
In split mode, positive and negative stages are defined separately. Users can set positive stages as well as negative stages, many as
they want. This feature is only for a selected user set. If you cannot see this. You are not in that user list.

1.6.How does Trading Work
When trading, the user profit if the market price moves in the same direction as the user’s speculation; however, if it takes the opposite
direction, the user incur a loss. It’s important to note that trading is inherently risky and could lose more than expected if don’t take the
appropriate risk management steps. Trading happens between two parties and often involves a dealer network. No central, physical
location only a virtual network of participants. Timings 24/7. Contracts are Customized. Counterparty risk, assets can be more volatile,

https://avishkanirmitha.github.io/karbon-doc/ 3/33
Introduction
1.1.Purpose
This platform facilitates effortless trading by allowing users to establish personalized settings, thereby enabling trades to be executed
automatically and requiring minimal human intervention. This platform could potentially assist in closing trades automatically when they
reach a profitable point. This streamlined approach ensures a user-friendly experience that stands out from traditional trading platforms
1.2.What is Trading
Trading is the buying and selling of financial instruments in order to make a profit. These instruments range from a variety of assets
assigned a financial value that can go up or down. Trading involves vigorous participation in the financial markets compared to
investing, which works on a buy-and-hold strategy. The success of trading is dependent on the ability of a trader to be profitable over a
period of time.
A trader is a person who gets involved in buying and selling a financial asset in any financial market. He or she can buy or sell either for
himself/herself or on behalf of another individual or institution. The main difference between an investor and a trader is the duration for
which he or she holds on to the asset.
A trader is a person who engages in the short-term purchasing and selling of equity either for an institution or for themselves.
1.3.What is a Candlestick
A candle stick is a type of price chart used in technical analysis that displays the high, low, open, and closing prices of a security for a
specific period.
wherein each candlestick details a single day’s trading. It has three essential features:
The body, which represents the open-to-close range
The wick, or shadow, that indicates the intra-day high and low
Max No Of Trades(Long and Short)
Long 
Maximum number of open long trades means, the user is not allowed to open the long trades more than the selected number. If
the user tries to open more trades “Karbon blocked this trade due to a maximum number of running long trades” message will be
displayed
Shor t 
Maximum number of open short trades means, the user is not allowed to open the short trades more than the selected number. If
the user tries to open more trades “Karbon blocked this trade due to a maximum number of running short trades” message will be
displayed
Leverage
Leverage is the ability to control a large position with a small amount of capital. It is a double-edged sword that can magnify both gains
and losses. The leverage is the amount of money that a trader is willing to risk on a trade. It is important to set the leverage to a level
that is comfortable for the trader and that will not cause financial hardship if the trade is lost.
Leverage types
